metadata.title: Title: Biomass Carbon Micro/nano-structures Derived from Ramie Fibers and Corncobs as Anode Materials for Lithium-ion and Sodium-ion Batteries

Highlights
• Ramie fibers and corncobs are used as precursors to prepare the biomass carbons. • The ramie fiber carbon (RFC) took on morphology of 3D micro-rods. • The corncob carbon (CC) possessed a 2D nanosheets structure. • Both RFC and CC exhibited outstanding electrochemical performances in LIBs and SIBs

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Three-dimensional (3D) rod-like carbon micro-structures derived from natural ramie fibers and two-dimensional (2D) carbon nanosheets derived from corncobs have been fabricated by heat treatment at 700 under argon atomsphere. The structure and morphology of the as-obtained ramie fiber carbon (RFC) and corncob carbon (CC) were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) technique. The electrochemical performances of the biomass carbon-based anode in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) were investigated. When tested as anode material for lithium ion batteries, both the RFC microrods and CC nanosheets exhibited high capacity, excellent rate capability, and stable cyclability. The specific capacity were still as high as 489 and 606 mAhg-1 after 180 cycles when cycled at room temperature in a 3.0 - 0.01 V potential (vs. Li/Li+) window at current density of 100 mAg−1, respectively, which are much higher than that of graphite (375 mAhg-1) under the same current density. Although the anodes in sodium ion batteries showed poorer specific capability than that in lithium-ion batteries, they still achieve a reversible sodium intercalation capacity of 122 and 139mAhg−1 with similar cycling stability. The feature of stable cycling performance makes the biomass carbon derived from natural ramie fibers and corncobs to be promising candidates as electrodes in rechargeable sodium-ion batteries and lithium-ion batteries. Key Words: Carbon materials; Electrical properties; Natural ramie fiber; Anode material 1. Introduction
Rechargeable lithium ion batteries (LIBs) continue to receive considerable
attention in the energy storage field due to the advantages of long lifetime, environmental benignity and high energy density, etc. [1-3] However, considering the limited and uneven distribution of lithium minerals, cost will become a major issue for future LIBs production in large-scale commercial manufacture. Recently, sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are attracting growing attention as post LIBs because of their low cost, abundant supply and similar chemistry between lithium and sodium [4-7].
Compared with the rapid development of cathode materials, few anode materials
have been reported for SIBs, and most anode materials for SIBs are carbon materials, such as hard carbons [8,9], petroleum cokes [10-12], carbon black [13], template carbons [14], pitch-based carbon-fibers [15], and polymers (poly( para-phenylene )) [16,17]. These materials have been identified to possess a variety of electrochemical performances due to their difference in morphologies, surface areas, pore size and percentage in the material. However, it’s still far from large-scale commercial production for these materials because of the high cost in the preparation process which depends on special equipments or conditions.
Bio-materials, which are generally abundant, renewable and environmental
friendly, have been widely used as precursors for making porous carbons. [18-20] Over the past decade, a variety of activated carbon were produced from biomass [21], most of which were used as catalysts, electrodes for supercapacitors, electrodes for LIBS and SIBS. For instance, activated carbon from pomelo peels [22], pig bones [23], fish scale [24], litchi shells [25], cassava [26], coconut shells [27]. Among these
natural bio-materials, ramie fiber has a smooth, soft texture that is not slippery, unlike many synthetic fibers. Natural Ramie fibers with excellent mechanical property are mainly used as textiles, artware and reinforced material. The implementation of low-cost biomass carbon derived from natural ramie fibers as battery electrodes depends strongly on the high surface area and huge pore volume. The corncob is a kind of lignocellulosic agricultural by products, which is rich in carbon, and the content of hemicellulose and cellulose is high. The hemicelluloses and cellulose could be converted into pentose and hexose, and this can be used as the carbon source to prepare carbon materials instead of fossil resources. In this work, we present a simple, efficient route to obtained biomass carbons through heat treatment derived from natural ramie fibers and corncobs. When they are tested as anode material for lithium ion batteries, both ramie fiber carbon (RFC) micro-rods and corncob carbon (CC) nano-sheets exhibited high capacity, excellent rate capability and stable cycle ability. This research work provides a new and simple approach for making use of natural resource to get novel carbon anode materials for both lithium-ion battery and sodium-ion battery applications.When tested as anode material for lithium ion batteries, both ramie fiber carbon (RFC) microrods and corncob carbon (CC) nanosheets exhibited high capacity, excellent rate capability, and stable cyclability. The specific capacity can maintain as high as 489 and 606 mAhg-1 after 180 cycles when cycled at room temperature in a 3.0 - 0.01 V potential (vs. Li/Li+) window at current density of 100 mAg−1, respectively, which are much higher than that of graphite (375 mAhg-1) under the same current density. Although the anodes in sodium ion batteries showed
poorer specific capability than that in lithium-ion batteries, they still achieve a reversible sodium intercalation capacity of 122 and 139 mAhg−1 with similar cycling stability. Meanwhile, the present work provides a new and simple approach for making use of natural resource to get novel carbon anode materials for both lithium-ion battery and sodium-ion battery applications. 2. Experimental 2.1. Preparation of ramie fiber carbon (RFC)
The ramie fibers raw material was first boiled in saturated sodium hydroxide
(NaOH ) for 1 h at 100 , and then the solution was neutralized and filtrated. The filtrated sample was soaked in H2O2 (30%) for 24 h. Finally, the fibers were again filtered and subsequently washed with distilled water and alcohol several times until the pH value reached at about 7. This was followed by drying at 100 for more than 10 h under vacuum. The as-collected fibers were first stabilized in an air atmosphere at 280 for 1 h, in order to induce dimensional stability of the carbon nanofibers. Subsequently, the above stabilized fibers were carbonized in a tube furnace at 700
for 3 h under argon atmosphere. The resultant products were then immersed in a certain concentration of hydrochloric acid solution (37 wt %) to remove possible insoluble inorganic compounds, and further dried at 80 in vacuum overnight. 2.2. Preparation of corncob carbon (CC)
The corn used in this study is obtained from local marketplace (Wuhan, China).
The corn were firstly washed and cooked in boiling water for 0.5 h. Then, the corncob were obtained from the corn and washed by water, and dried in vacuum at 80 °C for
24 h. The innermost part of corncob was ground in an agate mortar and stabilized in an air atmosphere at 280 for 1 h. Subsequently, the above stabilized precursor was carbonized in a tube furnace at 700 for 3 h under argon atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 min-1. The resultant products were then immersed in a certain concentration of hydrochloric acid solution (37wt %) to remove possible insoluble inorganic compounds, and further dried at 80 in vacuum overnight. 2.3. Characterization of samples
The structure and crystallinity of the sample were characterized using an X-ray
diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance) with Cu Kα radiation source (λ= 0.15406 nm) under a voltage of 40 KV and a current of 40 mA, and Raman spectrum on a Renishaw in Via reflex Raman microscope with 523 nm line of Ar-ion laser as excitation source. The morphology of the resulting compound was observed using a scanning electron microscope（SEM，Jeol，JSM-7100F）and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI, Tecnai G20). Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out on an Diamond instrument (Perkin Elmer, America) at 800 with a heating rate of 10 min-1 in N2. The Brunauer Emmett-Teller (BET) tests were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 porosimetry system and accelerated surface area. The pore size distribution (PSD) was estimated by means of Barret-Joyer Halenda (BJH) model and analyzing nitrogen adsorption data.

sections.heading: 2.4. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
Charge-discharge tests were performed using CR2025 coin-type cells in an
automatic battery tester system (Neware, China). The working electrode was
formulated from a mixture of 80 wt.% as-prepared powders, 10 wt.% acetylene black, and 10 wt.% poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) binder. Lithium foil was used as the counter electrode, and the electrolyte was 1 M LiPF6 in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DEC) (1:1, v/v). All test cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove box containing less than 1 ppm each of oxygen and moisture. The cells were discharged and charged at a constant current of 100 mAg-1 over a voltage range of 0.01 - 3.00 V (versus Li+/Li) at room temperature. The typical masses of electrode materials used in the experiment ranged from 5 mg to 8 mg. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) were performed on a CHI 660C electrochemical workstation. EIS were recorded by applying an AC voltage of 5 mV in a frequency range of 10 mHz to 100 kHz at the open circuit potential (OCP) of the cells. CV measurements were conducted from 0.01 to 3.0 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mVs-1. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Structure and morphology characterization
Figure 1a displays the XRD patterns of the as-obtained RFC and CC that are
treated in argon at about 700 , respectively. The crystallographic structure of the as-prepared sample was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As shown in XRD patterns of the biomass carbon samples in Figure 1a, two broad and weak diffraction peaks at around 23° and 43° corresponding to the (002) and (100) diffraction modes, are the characteristics of the amorphous carbon. The (002) peak around 23° indicates small domains of coherent and parallel stacking of the graphene sheets. The (100)
peak around 43° is typicality of honeycomb structure formed by sp2 hybridized carbons [28]. However, compared with the (002) and (100) peak of CC, that of the RFC sample slightly shifted to the left, especially for the (002) peak, which indicates that the interlamellar spacing between the (0 0 2) plane was extended according to Bragg's equation: 2d·sinθ=λ [29,30]. In addition, the intensity of the peaks for the RFC is lower than that of CC, showing that the RFC has a lower degree of graphitization, and the broad peaks of RFC also suggest that the synthesized carbon from ramie fiber is amorphous carbon [31].
The Roman spctra of RFC and CC can be seen in Figure 1b, all the Raman
spectra of the two samples show two remarkable peaks, the D-band (disordered carbon) lied on 1341 cm−1 and the G-band (graphitic carbon) located at 1592 cm−1. It is well known that the D-band and G-band correspond to sp3 hybridized carbon with disordered state and the sp2 hybridized carbon with graphite structure, respectively. The intensity ratio of the D band and G band, ID/IG, is known to be used to quantify the disorder degree of the carbon [32]. As can be seen from Figure 2, CC displays a lower intensity ratio of the D to the G band (ID/IG) of 0.83 than RFC (0.88). The relatively lower intensity ratios of calculated D and G bands indicate that the CC sample contained few defects, presenting a much more ordered state.
Meanwhile，thermal gravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out to investigate the
carbonization process of ramie fibers and corncobs in inert atmosphere.The TGA curves recorded with the RFC and CC precursors used between room temperature and 800 in a N2 flow are shown in Figure 1c，in which we can see that the TG curves
present a distinct weight loss stage from around 200 to 500 , and the large weight loss can be attributed to the loss of H2O, CO2 and CO, resulting from the escape of H and O atoms in the ramie fibers and corncobs[33]. Besides, a total weight loss of about 80% and 74% during the pyrolysis of ramie fibers and corncobs in N2 can be observed, respectively.
Figure 2a,b show the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and their
corresponding pore size distribution (PSD) curves for RFC and CC. Both of the carbon samples exhibit a type II isotherm in teams of the adsorbed nitrogen quantity significantly increase at P/P0≈0 and 1[34]. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the samples are summarized in Table 1. As can be seen, CC shows a larger specific surface area of 718.81 m2g−1, and RFC presents a lower specific surface area of 343.81 m2g−1. The PSD and pore volumes are determined by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, and the PSD curves show that the average pore diameter of CC is 2.59 nm in contrast to 2.56 nm for RFC, and the pore valume of CC is 0.4645 cm3g-1, which is also larger than that for RFC (0.22 cm3g-1 ),(Figure 2b). As is known, the high specific surface area can benefit the rapid electronic and ionic transport and the large pore volume can allow sufficient infiltration of the electrolyte and fast diffusion of lithium/sodium ion for LIBs/SIBs [33]. This may enable a higher specific capacity and more excellent rate performance of CC electrode than that for the RFC electrode.
The size, morphology, and microstructure of the samples were investigated by
scanning electron microscopy (SEM), the digital photos of the the natural ramie fiber
before annealing and after annealing at 700 °C under argon are shown in Figure 3.(a,b), in which we can see that the ramie fiber feature a morphology of silk, and the morphology can be maintained after high temperature heat-treatment. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of the as-prepared RFC is shown in Figure 3c. Figure 3c is an overall views of the as-synthesized biomass carbon, from which it reveals that the as-obtained carbon sample displays a long and randomly oriented three-dimensional rods with a uniform diameter distribution around 10 μm. The conductive 3D rod-like structures are favorable foreasier electrolyte access to the active materials and faster electronicand ionic migration when applied in LIBs and SIBs. The digital photo of the corn is shown in Figure 3d, the innermost part of corncob (in the red circle part of the digital photos) was carbonized by high temperature heat treatment. Figure 3e is the SEM image of the CC after annealing at 700 °C under argon, and we can see that all of these carbonized products present a sheet-like structure with a thickness of ~200 nm. The special two-dimensional (2D) nanosheet structure makes the CC sample possess a high surface area, which can provide a shot pathways to fast transportation of lithium/sodium ions insertion/extraction. Additionally, the high specific surface area of the biomass carbon sample facilitate infiltration of electrolyte, which give rise to high initial lithium/sodium utilization and rate capability [35]. The transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of RFC further give the evidences that the particles are rods-like, as presented in Figure 4a, and the high resolution TEM shows that the surface of these rods has rich micropores (Figure 4b). The TEM image of CC (Figure
4c) reveals that the amorphous two-dimensional nanosheet porous structure, which correspond with the SEM observation. Figure 4d shows a higher magnification TEM image in the edge of CC, in which a number of white spots can be clearly observed , implying abundant micropores in the CC. The unique pore-size distribution of CC could enable fast ion transport and allow sufficient infiltration of the electrolyte for LIBs and SIBs [33]. 3.2. Electrochemical properties
The electrochemical properties of the as-prepared carbon electrodes were
measured via coin cell testing. The galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles of the RFC and CC electrodes for LIBs measured in the potential range of 0.01-3.0 V at a constant current density of 100 mAg−1 are presented in Figure 5a and b. In general, the charge/discharge curves of both RFC and CC in LIBs show a steep slope and an ndistinct plateau, corresponding to intercalation of lithium ions between graphene layers and insertion into nanopores [36]. As for the RFC electrode, It is surprising that a large specific capacity of about 757 mAhg-1 is achieved at first cycle, and the reversible capacity is 432 mAhg-1 in the second cycle, which is much higher than the theoretical capacity of graphite (375mAhg-1). The discharge capacities of the carbon anode in the 1st, 2nd, 5th and 10th cycle are 757, 432, 399 and 389 mAhg-1, respectively; and the charge capacities of the anode in the 1st, 2nd, 5th and 10th cycle are 407, 402, 379 and 385 mAhg-1, respectively. A large irreversible capacity of 350 mAhg-1 is observed for the RFC electrode during the first discharge-charge process. This can be attributed to the formation of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film at the
electrode-electrolyte interface. As for the CC sample, the discharge capacities of the carbon anode in the 1st, 2nd, 5th and 10th cycle are 762, 443, 394 and 363 mAhg-1, respectively; and the charge capacities of the anode in the 1st, 2nd, 5th and 10th cycle are 415, 393, 378 and 359 mAhg-1, respectively.
It can be expected that the unique 3D rod-like micro-structure of the RFC
electrode and 2D nanosheet structure of the CC electrode could show good cycling performances. Figure 5c and d show the cycling performance of the RFC and CC electrode tested at 100 mAg−1 between 0.01 V and 3 V, respectively. It can be seen that the both carbon electrodes manifests excellent capacity retention properties in the lithium ion battery system. The reversible capacity of the RFC electrode in lithium ion battery system is above 389 mAhg-1 in the initial 11 cycles, as shown in Figure 5c, the capacity keeps increasing in the following cycles, and a capacity of above 523 mAhg-1 can be maintained after 180 cycles. In addition, the CC electrode also achieves a reversible lithium intercalation capacity of 443 mAhg−1 and even better cycling stability in lithium ion battery system. The reversible capacity of the electrodes is above 345 mAhg-1 in the initial 17 cycles, after which the capacity has been on the rise until 180 cycles, and a much larger capacity of 660 mAhg-1 is achieved in the 180th cycle. The phenomenon of capacity increasing during cycle process in both RFC and CC electrodes can be clearly seen, which has also been found in many other anode materials containing transition metal elements, while there is no accurate explanation for this phenomenon so far. The increasing trend in the capacity could also be related to similar explanations as for many other anode materials containing
transition metal elements, such as the formation and decomposition of a “polymeric layer” during deep discharge reactions [37,38] and the larger specific surface area obtained from the structural fragmentation during the cycling process [39]. Besides, this capacity increase of the carbon anodes may be considered that during the process of lithium ions insertion/extraction, carbon vacancies existed in RFC and CC are different and these vacancies are sites for storage of Li+ [40].
To further investigate the electrochemical performance of the biomass carbon
electrodes, rate capability was examined. As shown in Figure 5d, a good capacity retention is obtained at each current rate ranging from 100 mAg-1 to 500 mAg-1 for both RFC and CC electrode. It can be seen that the reversible capacities of the RFC electrode are ca. 313, 222 and 204 mAhg-1 at current densities of 100, 300 and 500mAg-1 in lithium ion battery system, respectively. It is noteworthy that the capacity can also be restored to ca. 304 mAhg-1 when the current density is returned to 100mAhg-1. And the reversible capacities of the CC electrode in lithium system are higher than that for the RFC electrode at current densities of 100, 300 and 500 mAg-1. The reversible capacities of the CC electrode are ca. 395, 275 and 251 mAhg-1 at current densities of 100, 300 and 500 mAhg-1, respectively, and the capacity can be restored to ca. 357 mAhg-1 when the current density is returned to 100mAhg-1.
Figure 6a and b reproduce the discharge/charge profiles for the obtained RFC
and CC in sodium system at the current density of 100 mAg-1. The biomass carbon electrodes deliver specific discharge and charge capacities of 349 and 133 mAhg-1 for RFC, 491 and 152 mAhg-1 for CC, respectively. The charge/discharge curves in SIBs
are somewhat similar to those in LIBs, although there are some changes in capacities and some subtle differences in potential values. The discharge/charge capacities of the 2nd, 5th, 10th cycles for the RFC electrode are 134/130, 123/122 mAhg-1, respectively. And the discharge/charge capacities of the 2nd, 5th, 10th cycles for the CC electrode are 162/149, 145/142 mAhg-1, respectively. The large irreversible capacity of 215 mAhg-1 for RFC and 329 mAhg-1 for CC can be ascribed to the irreversible reaction between sodium and surface functional group(s) as well as with the electrolyte forming a SEI layer.[41] Figure 6c shows the cycling performances of the RFC and CC electrodes at at a current density of 100 mAg−1 between 0.01 V and 3 V for 100 cycles in sodium system, as shown in Figure 6c, the reversible discharge capacity of the RFC electrode is 138 mAhg-1, and the electrode retains a reversible capacity of 122 mAhg-1 after 100 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention of 88.4%. As for the CC electrod, the reversible discharge capacity is 162 mAhg-1, which is much higher than that for RFC electrode. After 100 cycles, the CC electrode can still remain as high as 139 mAhg-1, with the capacity retention of 85.8%. The rate performance of the RFC and CC electrodes can be seen in Figure 6d, the cells were discharged and charged at various current densities (100, 300, 500mAg-1). The RFC electrode delivered a specific discharge capacity of 192, 119 and 93 mAhg-1 at 100, 300 and 500 mAg-1, respectively. When the current density restored back to 100 mAg-1, the specific capacity recovered to 136 mAhg-1, which shows the stable cycling performance of the RFC electrode. And the CC electrode presents a much better cycling performance, with a specific discharge capacity of 161, 125 and 103 mAhg-1
at 100, 300 and 500 mAg-1, respectively. When the current density restored back to 100 mAg-1, the specific capacity recovered to 157 mAhg-1. Based on the above results, it reveals that the CC electrode show much higher lithium/sodium storage capacity, cycle stability, and rate performance than the RFC electrode, demonstrating the advantage and high potential of 2D carbon nanosheets derived from corncobs for use as anodes for both LIBs and SIBs. By comparing lithium with sodium insertion behaviors in RFC and CC, it can be seen that both lithium and sodium can be inserted into the interlayer space at sloping region and nanopores at plateau region in disordered biomass carbons and the RFC and CC anodes in LIBs and SIBs show similar cycling stability. However, the layer spacing and pore size available for Li and Na are different because of the different ionic radius and ionic electronegativity between Li and Na. In addition, the carbon anodes have a relative higher reversible capacity at sloping region in LIBs than that at same region in SIBs and have a more significant portion of their capacity at a potential close to that of sodium metal itself, including the larger sodium-ion size, resulting in slower sodium-ion diffusion than lithium-ion diffusion [42].
For a better understanding of the electrochemical performance of the CC
electrode compared with the RFC electrode for lithium/sodium ion energy storage, the EIS spectra and linear fitting of the Warburg impedance of the RFC and CC electrodes in both lithium and sodium system were compiled on the basis of the Randles equivalent circuit shown in Figure 7. As shown in Figure 7a and b, the high frequency semicircle corresponds to the ohmic resistance, which could be attributed to the
resistance of the electrolyte and/or the contact resistance [43]. The lower frequency inclined line at approximately 45° represents the Warburg impedance, which is associated with lithium-ion diffusion in the carbon electrodes [44]. In this model, Rs, Cdl, Rct and Zw represent the electrolyte resistance, a constant phase element (CPE) corresponding to the double layer capacitance, the charge transfer resistance, and a Warburg impedance corresponding to the lithium ion diffusion [45], respectively. From the Nyquist plots, it is revealed that the charge transfer resistance of the CC electrode had smaller value of 129.2Ω which is less than that for the RFC electrode (239.7Ω) when tested in lithium system (Figure 7a). And as for the sodium system, the CC electrode also posessed a much smaller Rct value of 361.2Ω than that for the RFC electrode (Figure 7b). These results suggested that the electronic conductivity of the CC electrode was better than that of the RFC electrode in both lithium and sodium system. The remaining inclined lines in the low frequency range in the EIS spectra were attributed to the Warburg impedance (Zw). As shown in Figure 7c and d, the Warburg coefficient (Aw) is equal to the slope of the Z’ vs. ω-1/2 line at low frequency, where ω is the angular frequency of the alternating current. The numerical value of the Li+ diffusion coefficient in the electrode can be estimated from the following equation [46]:

where Vm is the molar volume of the carbon materials, S is the apparent surface area of the electrode, and (dE)/(dx) is the slope of the open-circuit potential vs. the mobile ion concentration x at each x value. Thus, the numerical values of Vm, S, and (dE)/(dx)
are constant for the model test cells, and the Li+ diffusion coefficient is in direct proportion to (1/Aw)2. The Warburg coefficients (Aw) of CC and RFC are 108.5 and 141.7Ωs-1/2 in lithium system, and 171.5 and 187.4Ωs-1/2, respectively, further confirming that the ionic conductivity of CC is better than that of RFC in both lithium and sodium system.
In order to investigate the mechanisms of the CC electrode in LIBs and SIBs, the
cyclic voltammogram (CV) experiments carried out on the CC electrode for the first five cycles are presented in Figure 8. Figure 8a shows the CV curves of the CC electrode of the voltage range between 0.01 and 3.00 V at a scanning rate of 0.1 mVs-1 in lithium system. As shown in Figure 8a, the cathodic peak at 0.5 V in the initial cycle is due to the decomposition of electrolyte and its reaction with the anode surface, forming the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer [47]. In the observed anodic curves of CC electrode at first cycle, a wide anodic peak at about 1.1 V can be observed which suggest reversible some SEI components oxidation. [37] The reduction peaks center at 0.5V shows a small shift to 1.0 V in the following cathodic scans owing to the activation of the electrode. The CV curves of the CC electrode in sodium system are presented in Figure 8b, there is a broad reduction plateau between 0.2 and 0.5 V during the initial cathodic scan, indicative of SEI formation, and it also shifted to ~0.75V in the following curves. The potential for SEI formation on CC anode in SIBs is different from in LIBs, attributed to the difference of standard electrode potential between E0 (Li/Li+) and E0 (Na/Na+) for aqueous solutions [48]. In addition, it is found that the CV curves almost overlapped in the subsequent scans, and
the cathodic and anodic peaks maintain very stable , indicating a good cyclability and good reactive reversibility of the CC electrode in both LIBs and SIBs.[49]

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The unique 3D rod-like carbon micro-structure anodes derived from natural
ramie fibers and 2D carbon nano-sheets derived from corncobs have been successfully fabricated by carbonization in Argon atmosphere at heat treatment temperatures about 700 . As anode materials for LIBs and SIBs, the biomass carbon electrodes exhibit high reversible capacity, good capacity retention and enhanced rate capability. Considering its low cost, simple preparation and great performance, the biomass carbon materials derived from ramie fibers and corncobs can be innovative and promising anode materials for future application in LIBs and SIBs. Meanwhile, the present work provides an effective measure for making use of natural resources to prepare biomass carbon as high performance anode materials for both LIBs and SIBs application.
